### Third-Line
- **Epinephrine** 0.1-0.5 mcg/kg/min if inadequate response to norepinephrine + vasopressin
- **Phenylephrine**: Consider only in pure vasodilatory shock or significant tachyarrhythmias limiting norepinephrine

### Inotropic Support
- **Dobutamine** 2-20 mcg/kg/min if evidence of myocardial dysfunction (low cardiac output despite adequate filling pressures)

## Source Control
- Identify and address within **6-12 hours** when feasible
- Drain abscesses (percutaneous or surgical)
- Debride necrotic tissue (necrotizing fasciitis requires emergent surgical debridement)
- Remove infected devices (central lines, urinary catheters, prosthetic material)
- Operative repair of perforated viscus

## Adjunctive Therapies
- **Corticosteroids**: Hydrocortisone 50 mg IV q6h if shock refractory to adequate fluids and vasopressors (norepinephrine >= 0.25 mcg/kg/min for >= 4 hours); taper over 3-7 days
- **Stress ulcer prophylaxis**: PPI or H2 blocker in mechanically ventilated patients
- **Glucose control**: Target 144-180 mg/dL; avoid hypoglycemia
- **VTE prophylaxis**: LMWH preferred unless contraindicated; use pneumatic compression if anticoagulation contraindicated

## Reassessment and De-escalation
- Reassess clinical status, lactate, and hemodynamics at 3 and 6 hours
- Narrow antibiotics based on culture results at 48-72 hours
- Procalcitonin-guided de-escalation: consider stopping antibiotics when procalcitonin < 0.5 ng/mL or decreased by >= 80% from peak
- Typical antibiotic duration: 7-10 days; shorter courses acceptable for urinary source with adequate control

# Hemorrhagic Stroke (Intracerebral Hemorrhage) Management

## Definition
Spontaneous (non-traumatic) bleeding into the brain parenchyma, often with extension into the ventricular system. Accounts for approximately 10-15% of all strokes with significantly higher mortality than ischemic stroke.

## Common Etiologies
- **Hypertension** (most common; deep structures: basal ganglia, thalamus, pons, cerebellum)
- Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (lobar hemorrhages in elderly)
- Anticoagulant or antiplatelet therapy
- Vascular malformations (AVM, cavernous malformation)
- Coagulopathy or thrombocytopenia
- Hemorrhagic conversion of ischemic stroke
- Illicit drug use (cocaine, amphetamines)
- Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis

## ICH Score (Prognostic Tool)
Assign points to estimate 30-day mortality:

| Component | Criteria | Points |
|-----------|----------|--------|
| GCS | 3-4 | 2 |
| GCS | 5-12 | 1 |
| GCS | 13-15 | 0 |
| ICH volume | >= 30 mL | 1 |
| ICH volume | < 30 mL | 0 |
| IVH present | Yes | 1 |
| IVH present | No | 0 |
| Infratentorial origin | Yes | 1 |
| Infratentorial origin | No | 0 |
| Age | >= 80 | 1 |
| Age | < 80 | 0 |

- **Score 0**: ~0% mortality
- **Score 1**: ~13% mortality
- **Score 2**: ~26% mortality
- **Score 3**: ~72% mortality
- **Score 4-5**: ~90-100% mortality

**Note**: The ICH score should not be used in isolation to make withdrawal-of-care decisions; early aggressive care is recommended regardless of initial score.

## Acute Blood Pressure Management
- **Target SBP < 140 mmHg** within 1 hour of presentation (per AHA/ASA 2022 guidelines and INTERACT2/ATACH-2 trials)
- Avoid SBP < 110 mmHg (associated with AKI and worse outcomes)
- **Preferred agents**:
  - Nicardipine infusion: start 5 mg/hr, titrate by 2.5 mg/hr q5-15 min (max 15 mg/hr)
  - Clevidipine infusion: start 1-2 mg/hr, titrate q90 seconds
  - Labetalol 10-20 mg IV q10-20 min (bolus) or infusion 2-8 mg/min
- Arterial line placement recommended for continuous BP monitoring
- Maintain target for at least 24-72 hours

## Reversal of Anticoagulation

### Warfarin (Target INR < 1.3 within 4 hours)
- **4-factor PCC (Kcentra)**: 25-50 units/kg IV based on INR (preferred over FFP)
- **Vitamin K**: 10 mg IV over 10-20 minutes (for sustained reversal; slow onset)
- FFP 10-15 mL/kg only if PCC unavailable

### Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs)
- **Dabigatran**: Idarucizumab (Praxbind) 5 g IV (two 2.5 g boluses); if unavailable, use activated PCC (FEIBA) 50 units/kg
- **Rivaroxaban/Apixaban/Edoxaban**: Andexanet alfa (Andexxa) per dosing protocol; if unavailable, 4-factor PCC 50 units/kg
- Consider activated charcoal if DOAC ingested within 2 hours

### Heparin
- Protamine sulfate: 1 mg per 100 units of heparin given in previous 2-3 hours (max 50 mg)

### Antiplatelet Agents
- Platelet transfusion is **not routinely recommended** (PATCH trial showed harm)
- Consider desmopressin (DDAVP) 0.3 mcg/kg IV if aspirin-related ICH

## Surgical Indications
- **Cerebellar hemorrhage > 3 cm** with neurologic deterioration, brainstem compression, or hydrocephalus: emergent surgical evacuation
- **Lobar hemorrhage > 30 mL** within 1 cm of cortical surface: consider minimally invasive surgery (MISTIE III) or craniotomy in deteriorating patients
- **Intraventricular hemorrhage with hydrocephalus**: External ventricular drain (EVD) with or without intraventricular tPA (CLEAR III trial)
- Deep basal ganglia hemorrhage: surgery generally not beneficial
- Decompressive craniectomy may be considered for large hemorrhages with refractory elevated ICP

## Monitoring and Supportive Care
- ICU admission with neurochecks q1h for first 24 hours
- Repeat CT head at 6 hours or with any neurologic change (hematoma expansion occurs in ~30%)
- Maintain normoglycemia (glucose 140-180 mg/dL)
- Maintain normothermia (treat fever aggressively; target temp < 37.5C)
- DVT prophylaxis: pneumatic compression devices immediately; consider LMWH at 24-48 hours if hemorrhage stable
- Seizure management: treat clinical seizures; routine prophylactic antiepileptics not recommended unless lobar ICH
- Continuous EEG monitoring if decreased consciousness unexplained by hemorrhage size

# Acute Ischemic Stroke Management

## Overview
Ischemic stroke results from arterial occlusion causing cerebral ischemia. Rapid evaluation and treatment are critical. Time-sensitive interventions include IV thrombolysis and endovascular thrombectomy.

## NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS)
The NIHSS is a 15-item neurologic assessment scored 0-42:
- **0**: No stroke symptoms
- **1-4**: Minor stroke
- **5-15**: Moderate stroke
- **16-20**: Moderate to severe stroke
- **21-42**: Severe stroke

### NIHSS Components
Level of consciousness, gaze, visual fields, facial palsy, motor arm (L/R), motor leg (L/R), limb ataxia, sensory, best language, dysarthria, extinction/inattention.

## Acute Assessment (Door-to-Needle Target: < 60 minutes)
- ABCs and vital signs; continuous cardiac monitoring
- Point-of-care glucose (exclude hypoglycemia as stroke mimic)
- Non-contrast CT head: exclude hemorrhage (must precede tPA)
- CT angiography (CTA) of head and neck: identify large vessel occlusion (LVO)
- CT perfusion: assess salvageable penumbra (especially for extended window cases)
- Labs: CBC, BMP, coagulation studies, troponin, type and screen

## IV Thrombolysis (Alteplase / Tenecteplase)

### Alteplase (tPA) - Within 4.5 Hours of Symptom Onset
- **Dose**: 0.9 mg/kg IV (max 90 mg); 10% as bolus over 1 minute, remainder infused over 60 minutes
- **Key Inclusion**: Measurable neurologic deficit, CT without hemorrhage, symptom onset clearly defined
- **Key Exclusions**:
  - Active internal bleeding or known bleeding diathesis
  - Platelet count < 100,000/mcL
  - INR > 1.7 or PT > 15 seconds
  - Therapeutic LMWH within 24 hours
  - Blood glucose < 50 mg/dL
  - Major surgery or serious trauma within 14 days
  - History of intracranial hemorrhage
  - **3-4.5 hour window additional exclusions**: Age > 80, NIHSS > 25, oral anticoagulant use, history of both DM and prior ischemic stroke

### Tenecteplase (Emerging Alternative)
- 0.25 mg/kg IV bolus (max 25 mg); single bolus administration offers logistical advantages
- Noninferior to alteplase, particularly for LVO patients proceeding to thrombectomy

## Endovascular Thrombectomy - Within 24 Hours for LVO
- **Indications**: Confirmed LVO (ICA, M1, proximal M2, basilar artery) on CTA
- **Standard window (0-6 hours)**: NIHSS >= 6, pre-stroke mRS 0-1, ASPECTS >= 6
- **Extended window (6-24 hours)**: Must demonstrate favorable perfusion imaging (mismatch between infarct core and ischemic penumbra per DAWN or DEFUSE-3 criteria)
- Thrombectomy should not delay IV tPA; administer tPA first if eligible, then proceed to angiography suite
- Target reperfusion: TICI 2b/3 (successful reperfusion of >= 50% of affected territory)

## Blood Pressure Management

### Pre-Thrombolysis
- Treat only if BP > 185/110 mmHg (to qualify for tPA)
- Agents: labetalol 10-20 mg IV, nicardipine infusion 5-15 mg/hr, clevidipine

### Post-Thrombolysis (First 24 Hours)
- Maintain BP < 180/105 mmHg for 24 hours after tPA administration
- Frequent monitoring: q15 min for 2 hours, then q30 min for 6 hours, then q1h

### No Thrombolysis Given
- Permissive hypertension up to 220/120 mmHg unless end-organ damage, aortic dissection, or hypertensive emergency
- Gradually lower BP by 15% in first 24 hours if treatment indicated

## Secondary Prevention
- **Antiplatelet therapy**: Aspirin 325 mg within 24-48 hours (delay 24 hours if tPA given); dual antiplatelet (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 21 days in minor stroke (NIHSS <= 3) or high-risk TIA
- **Statin therapy**: High-intensity statin (atorvastatin 80 mg or rosuvastatin 20 mg) regardless of LDL
- **Atrial fibrillation**: Initiate anticoagulation (typically DOAC) at 4-14 days post-stroke depending on infarct size (1-3-6-12 day rule based on severity)
- **Carotid stenosis**: Carotid endarterectomy or stenting for symptomatic stenosis >= 50% (NASCET criteria)
- **Blood pressure control**: Target < 130/80 mmHg after acute phase; initiate antihypertensives before discharge
- **Lifestyle**: Smoking cessation, exercise, Mediterranean-style diet, diabetes optimization (HbA1c < 7%)

# Suicide Risk Assessment

## Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS)

The C-SSRS is a standardized, evidence-based tool for assessing suicidal ideation and behavior.

### Screening Questions
1. **Wish to be dead**: "Have you wished you were dead or wished you could go to sleep and not wake up?"
2. **Active suicidal ideation**: "Have you actually had any thoughts of killing yourself?"
3. **Ideation with method**: "Have you been thinking about how you might do this?"
4. **Intent without plan**: "Have you had these thoughts and had some intention of acting on them?"
5. **Intent with plan**: "Have you started to work out or worked out the details of how to kill yourself?"

A "yes" to questions 3-5 warrants immediate psychiatric evaluation.

## Risk Factors

### Static Risk Factors
- Prior suicide attempt (single strongest predictor)
- Family history of suicide
- History of childhood abuse or trauma
- Male sex (higher completion rate)
- Age >65 or 15-24 years
- Chronic medical illness or chronic pain

### Dynamic Risk Factors
- Current psychiatric diagnosis (depression, bipolar, schizophrenia, borderline PD)
- Recent psychiatric hospitalization (within 90 days of discharge)
- Active substance use disorder
- Acute psychosocial stressors (job loss, divorce, bereavement, legal problems)
- Access to lethal means (especially firearms)
- Social isolation and hopelessness
- Recent self-harm or increasing ideation intensity

## Protective Factors
- Strong social support and connectedness
- Responsibility to children or family
- Religious or spiritual beliefs against suicide
- Active engagement in mental health treatment
- Problem-solving and coping skills
- Reasons for living (future-oriented thinking)

## Safety Planning (Stanley-Brown Model)

A collaborative, written safety plan should include six steps:

1. **Warning signs**: Identify personal triggers and early warning thoughts/feelings
2. **Internal coping strategies**: Activities the patient can do alone to distract (exercise, music, breathing)
3. **Social contacts for distraction**: Friends or family who can help redirect attention
4. **People to contact during crisis**: Trusted individuals the patient can tell about suicidal feelings
5. **Professional resources**: Therapist, psychiatrist, 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline, local crisis services, emergency department
6. **Lethal means restriction**: Steps to reduce access to methods

## Lethal Means Restriction

- **Firearms**: Counsel on temporary removal from home; offer storage with trusted individual, law enforcement, or gun shop. Firearms account for >50% of suicide deaths.
- **Medications**: Limit quantities prescribed; recommend locking up or removing stockpiled medications
- **Other means**: Assess and address access to sharp objects, ligatures, heights, or vehicles

## When to Hospitalize

### Criteria for Inpatient Psychiatric Admission
- Active suicidal ideation with plan and intent
- Recent serious suicide attempt requiring medical treatment
- Inability to contract for safety or cooperate with outpatient plan
- Command auditory hallucinations to harm self
- Severe agitation or psychosis with suicidal ideation
- Lack of adequate outpatient support or follow-up
- Active intoxication with suicidal statements and inability to assess once sober

### Outpatient Management May Be Appropriate When
- Passive ideation without plan or intent
- Strong protective factors and social support
- Patient is cooperative and engaged in safety planning
- Reliable follow-up within 24-72 hours can be arranged
- Lethal means have been secured

## Documentation Requirements
- Document risk assessment findings using structured format
- Record risk level (low, moderate, high, imminent)
- Note clinical rationale for disposition decision
- Document safety plan discussion and means restriction counseling
- Record follow-up plan and communication with outpatient providers

# Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) Management

## Definition
Traumatic brain injury is an alteration in brain function or pathology caused by an external mechanical force. Severity is classified by the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score at presentation.

## Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

### Eye Opening (E: 1-4)
- 4: Spontaneous
- 3: To voice/command
- 2: To pain
- 1: None

### Verbal Response (V: 1-5)
- 5: Oriented
- 4: Confused
- 3: Inappropriate words
- 2: Incomprehensible sounds
- 1: None

### Motor Response (M: 1-6)
- 6: Obeys commands
- 5: Localizes pain
- 4: Withdrawal (flexion)
- 3: Abnormal flexion (decorticate)
- 2: Extension (decerebrate)
- 1: None

**Total GCS range: 3-15**

## TBI Classification by Severity

### Mild TBI (GCS 13-15)
- Includes concussion
- LOC < 30 minutes, post-traumatic amnesia < 24 hours
- Most patients recover fully; counsel on post-concussive syndrome
- Discharge with reliable observer and head injury return precautions

### Moderate TBI (GCS 9-12)
- LOC 30 minutes to 24 hours, PTA 1-7 days
- ICU admission with frequent neurochecks
- Repeat neuroimaging at 6-8 hours or with clinical change

### Severe TBI (GCS 3-8)
- LOC > 24 hours, PTA > 7 days
- Requires intubation for airway protection (GCS <= 8 = intubate)
- ICU management with ICP monitoring
- Neurosurgical consultation mandatory

## Imaging Indications

### CT Head Without Contrast (First-Line)
Apply the **Canadian CT Head Rule** (for mild TBI, GCS 13-15):
- **High risk (need CT)**: GCS < 15 at 2 hours post-injury, suspected open/depressed skull fracture, signs of basal skull fracture, >= 2 episodes of vomiting, age >= 65
- **Medium risk**: Retrograde amnesia > 30 minutes, dangerous mechanism (pedestrian struck, fall > 3 feet or 5 stairs, ejection from vehicle)

### CT Angiography
- Indicated when cervical spine fracture involves transverse foramen, Le Fort II/III fractures, or focal neurologic deficit suggesting vascular injury

### MRI Brain
- More sensitive for diffuse axonal injury, posterior fossa lesions, and subacute blood products
- Obtain when CT does not explain neurologic deficits

## Intracranial Pressure (ICP) Management

### Indications for ICP Monitoring
- Severe TBI (GCS 3-8) with abnormal CT (hematoma, contusion, edema, compressed cisterns)
- Severe TBI with normal CT **if** age > 40, motor posturing, or SBP < 90 mmHg
- Target ICP < 22 mmHg and cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) 60-70 mmHg

### Tiered ICP Management

**Tier 1 (Initial Measures)**
- Head of bed elevation 30 degrees, midline head positioning
- Adequate sedation and analgesia (propofol, fentanyl)
- Avoid hyperthermia (target normothermia)
- Avoid hypotension (SBP > 100 mmHg if age 50-69; SBP > 110 if age 15-49 or >= 70)
- Maintain PaCO2 35-40 mmHg (avoid routine hyperventilation)
- CSF drainage via EVD if in place

**Tier 2 (Escalation)**
- Hyperosmolar therapy:
  - Mannitol 0.25-1 g/kg IV bolus (hold if serum osmolality > 320 mOsm/L or osmolar gap > 20)
  - Hypertonic saline (23.4% NaCl 30 mL IV via central line, or 3% NaCl infusion targeting Na 145-155 mEq/L)
- Brief hyperventilation to PaCO2 30-35 mmHg (short-term rescue only)

**Tier 3 (Refractory Elevated ICP)**
- Decompressive craniectomy (DECRA/RESCUEicp trials: reduces ICP, may improve survival but with variable functional outcome)
- Pentobarbital coma: load 5-10 mg/kg IV, infusion 1-4 mg/kg/hr titrated to burst suppression on continuous EEG
- Therapeutic hypothermia (32-35C) is controversial; not routinely recommended per BTF guidelines

## Seizure Prophylaxis
- **Early post-traumatic seizures** (within 7 days) occur in 10-15% of severe TBI
- Levetiracetam 500-1000 mg IV/PO q12h **or** phenytoin (load 20 mg/kg IV, then 100 mg IV/PO q8h) for **7 days**
- Discontinue at 7 days unless clinical seizures occur (prophylaxis beyond 7 days does not prevent late epilepsy)
- Continuous EEG monitoring recommended in severe TBI patients with unexplained decreased consciousness

## Additional Supportive Care
- Maintain euvolemia; avoid hypotonic fluids (use normal saline as primary crystalloid)
- Glucose control: target 80-180 mg/dL; avoid hypoglycemia
- DVT prophylaxis: pneumatic compression immediately; LMWH at 24-72 hours if hemorrhage stable on repeat imaging
- Nutritional support: initiate enteral feeding within 24-72 hours
- Pituitary dysfunction screening (cortisol, TSH) in moderate-severe TBI

# Thyroid Disorders

## Hypothyroidism

### Diagnosis
- **Primary hypothyroidism**: Elevated TSH with low free T4
- **Subclinical hypothyroidism**: Elevated TSH (4.5-10 mIU/L) with normal free T4
- Common causes: Hashimoto thyroiditis (most common), post-radioactive iodine, post-thyroidectomy, medications (lithium, amiodarone), iodine deficiency

### Levothyroxine (LT4) Dosing

**Initial Dosing**:
- Young, healthy adults: 1.6 mcg/kg/day (full replacement dose)
- Elderly or coronary artery disease: Start 12.5-25 mcg/day; increase by 12.5-25 mcg every 4-6 weeks
- Severe/prolonged hypothyroidism: Start low and titrate slowly

**Administration**:
- Take on empty stomach, 30-60 minutes before breakfast or at bedtime 3+ hours after last meal
- Separate from calcium, iron, PPIs, and cholestyramine by at least 4 hours
- Consistent timing improves TSH stability

### TSH Targets
- **General adult population**: 0.5-2.5 mIU/L (lower half of reference range)
- **Elderly (>70 years)**: 1.0-5.0 mIU/L (higher target acceptable; overtreatment increases atrial fibrillation, osteoporosis, and fracture risk)
- **Pregnancy**: Trimester-specific targets; first trimester <2.5 mIU/L, second/third trimester <3.0 mIU/L
- **Thyroid cancer (DTC) suppression therapy**: 0.1-0.5 mIU/L for intermediate risk; <0.1 mIU/L for high risk

### Monitoring
- Recheck TSH 6-8 weeks after dose initiation or adjustment
- Once stable, monitor TSH every 6-12 months
- Dose adjustments may be needed with weight change, pregnancy, aging, or interacting medications

### Subclinical Hypothyroidism
- **TSH >10 mIU/L**: Treat with levothyroxine (high progression rate to overt hypothyroidism)
- **TSH 4.5-10 mIU/L**: Consider treatment if symptomatic, positive TPO antibodies, dyslipidemia, or pregnancy/planning pregnancy
- **Elderly with TSH 4.5-10**: Generally observe without treatment unless symptomatic (TRUST trial showed no benefit)

## Hyperthyroidism

### Diagnosis
- Suppressed TSH with elevated free T4 and/or free T3
- Common causes: Graves disease (most common), toxic multinodular goiter, toxic adenoma, thyroiditis (subacute, postpartum), exogenous thyroid hormone

### Treatment Options

**Methimazole (MMI)**:
- First-line antithyroid drug for most patients
- Starting dose: 10-30 mg/day depending on severity; maintenance 5-10 mg/day
- Monitor CBC and LFTs at baseline and if symptoms develop
- Adverse effects: Agranulocytosis (0.2-0.5%), hepatotoxicity, rash, arthralgia
- Contraindicated in first trimester of pregnancy (teratogenic)

**Propylthiouracil (PTU)**:
- Reserved for first trimester of pregnancy and thyroid storm
- Dose: 100-200 mg three times daily; maintenance 50-100 mg TID
- Higher hepatotoxicity risk (including liver failure); more frequent dosing
- Preferred in first trimester (lower teratogenic risk than MMI)

**Radioactive Iodine (RAI) Ablation**:
- Definitive treatment for Graves disease and toxic nodular disease
- Contraindicated in pregnancy, breastfeeding, and moderate-to-severe Graves ophthalmopathy
- Most patients become hypothyroid within 6-12 months and require lifelong LT4
- Discontinue methimazole 3-5 days before RAI

**Thyroidectomy**:
- Indicated for large goiter with compressive symptoms, suspected malignancy, moderate-to-severe ophthalmopathy, or patient preference
- Risks: Hypoparathyroidism, recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

**Beta-Blockers**:
- Propranolol 20-40 mg TID or atenolol 25-50 mg daily for symptomatic relief (tachycardia, tremor, anxiety)
- Use as adjunct until euthyroid state achieved

## Thyroid Storm

### Diagnosis (Burch-Wartofsky Score)
Clinical diagnosis based on: Temperature >38.5C, tachycardia >130, atrial fibrillation, CNS dysfunction (agitation, delirium, seizure, coma), GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice), heart failure. Score >=45: Highly suggestive of thyroid storm.

### Management (Treat Simultaneously)
1. **PTU** 500-1000 mg loading dose, then 250 mg every 4 hours (blocks synthesis AND peripheral conversion)
2. **Iodine solution** (SSKI 5 drops q6h or Lugol solution 10 drops q8h) -- give at least 1 hour AFTER PTU to prevent iodine utilization
3. **Hydrocortisone** 100 mg IV every 8 hours (blocks T4 to T3 conversion, treats relative adrenal insufficiency)
4. **Propranolol** 60-80 mg PO every 4-6 hours (or esmolol IV if unable to take PO)
5. **Cholestyramine** 4g QID (binds thyroid hormone in enterohepatic circulation)
6. **Supportive care**: Cooling measures for hyperthermia (avoid aspirin -- displaces T4 from binding proteins), IV fluids, glucose, ICU monitoring
7. **Plasmapheresis**: Consider for refractory cases

## Subclinical Hyperthyroidism
- TSH <0.1 mIU/L with normal free T4/T3: Consider treatment if age >65, cardiac risk factors, osteoporosis, or postmenopausal
- TSH 0.1-0.4 mIU/L with normal free T4/T3: Generally observe with repeat testing in 3-6 months

# Urinary Tract Infection (UTI) Management

## Classification
- **Uncomplicated cystitis**: Lower UTI in non-pregnant women without structural abnormalities
- **Complicated UTI**: UTI with structural/functional abnormality, male sex, pregnancy, immunosuppression, indwelling catheter
- **Pyelonephritis**: Upper UTI involving renal parenchyma
- **Catheter-associated UTI (CAUTI)**: Symptoms + culture ≥1000 CFU/mL with catheter in place within 48 hours

## Diagnosis
- Symptoms: Dysuria, frequency, urgency, suprapubic pain (cystitis); fever, flank pain, CVA tenderness (pyelonephritis)
- Urinalysis: Pyuria (>10 WBC/HPF), positive leukocyte esterase, nitrites (Gram-negative bacteria)
- Culture: ≥100,000 CFU/mL (symptomatic: ≥1000 CFU/mL may be significant)

## Uncomplicated Cystitis — First-Line Treatment
- **Nitrofurantoin** 100mg BID × 5 days (avoid if CrCl <30)
- **TMP-SMX** 160/800mg BID × 3 days (if local resistance <20%)
- **Fosfomycin** 3g single dose (less effective than above)
- **Avoid** fluoroquinolones for uncomplicated cystitis (reserve for complicated infections)

## Pyelonephritis
### Outpatient (mild, no nausea/vomiting)
- **Ciprofloxacin** 500mg BID × 7 days, or **Levofloxacin** 750mg daily × 5 days
- **TMP-SMX** 160/800mg BID × 14 days (if susceptible)
- Consider single dose IM ceftriaxone 1g before starting oral therapy

### Inpatient (severe, sepsis, unable to tolerate PO)
- **Ceftriaxone** 1g IV daily, or **Ciprofloxacin** 400mg IV BID
- **Piperacillin-tazobactam** or **Meropenem** if ESBL suspected
- Switch to PO when afebrile ≥48 hours and tolerating PO

## Complicated UTI
- Obtain culture before starting empiric therapy
- Broader spectrum: Fluoroquinolone, ceftriaxone, or piperacillin-tazobactam
- Duration: 7-14 days depending on severity and response
- Address underlying cause (obstruction, catheter removal/exchange)

## Special Populations
- **Pregnancy**: Treat asymptomatic bacteriuria; safe antibiotics: amoxicillin, cephalexin, nitrofurantoin (avoid near term)
- **Men**: Always consider complicated; evaluate for prostatitis; duration typically 7-14 days
- **Recurrent UTI** (≥3/year): Consider prophylaxis — low-dose nitrofurantoin, post-coital prophylaxis, vaginal estrogen (postmenopausal)
